items.description: River Leen and Day Brook in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The risk of flooding from heavy rainfall and thunderstorms has now passed for today, Sunday 8th August 2021.  Further heavy showers are forecast for tomorrow daytime, Monday 9th August 2021.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the River Wey are falling after heavy rainfall yesterday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed and trash screens and in the area checking defences. 
The weather will remain showery. Stay safe and be aware of your surroundings.
This message will be updated this evening 09/08/21, or as the situation changes.

Following heavy rain overnight, the water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone is now falling. In Sandown, it continues to rise. Currently, there will be some water ponded on fields, footpaths, access and cycle tracks adjacent to the river. While heavy showers continue to affect the mainland, very little, if no rain is forecast on the Island for the rest of the day (Monday 09/08/21). In Alverstone, the water level will continue to fall. In Sandown, the river should peak around 19:00 this evening. However, it will remain high and at a similar level, until at least 23:00, before finally lowering. The river will not affect property, but Golf Links Road may experience some minor impact flooding. Light showers are forecast tomorrow (10/08/21), with up to 5mm expected. The weather should then remain fairly dry until Friday (13/08/21). This will give the river some opportunity to recover. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking, driving or cycling through flood water. This message will be updated or removed by 10:00 on Tuesday 10/08/21.

The River Uck has peaked and is falling in Buxted and Uckfield, following Monday's heavy rain. In Isfield, minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads and gardens will continue, but the river should begin to fall by 21:00 Monday (09/08/2021). Only isolated showers are forecast Monday and Tuesday. Which should allow water levels in all communities to return to normal by 10:00 Tuesday morning (10/08/2021). As a precaution, please keep flood resilience measures in place Monday and Tuesday while river levels remain high. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 Tuesday 10/08/2021.

River levels through Buxted have peaked and are falling, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Residual flood impacts might remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads, but with only isolated showers forecast Monday (09/08/21) and Tuesday(10/08/21), the River Uck should continue to fall overnight, and a normal water level should have returned by Tuesday morning. As a precaution, please keep flood resilience measures in place Monday and Tuesday while river levels remain high. At the moment, the weather forecast predicts the end of the week should also remain dry. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this warning if the risk of flooding returns.

The river at Fittleworth is still high, is rising again following Monday's heavy rain, and will continue to rise until late Tuesday afternoon. It is possible that water levels in Fittleworth Tuesday morning could be higher than those measured Sunday, but the peak water level is unlikely to be more than 10 to 20 centimetres higher than Sunday. Only minor flood impacts are currently predicted, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. In Liss and Sheet river levels have already returned to normal. In Iping river levels have peaked and will slowly fall Monday evening. At Lodsbridge near Selham the river level will peak around 02:00 Tuesday (10/08/2021), at a similar height as seen Sunday. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday and Tuesday. As a precaution, please keep flood resilience measures in place Monday and Tuesday while river levels remain high and rising. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 10/08/2021.
River levels in upper Aire continue to fall. The washlands have started to empty. There remains chance of scattered heavy showers through the evening and into tomorrow.

items.description: River Glaze catchment including Leigh and East Wigan

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall this morning. Flooding is expected from 10am this morning, Monday 9 August. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst. Property flooding is not expected.

The heavy rainfall is expected to clear later this morning, but further heavy isolated showers are possible through the rest of the day. We expect river levels to remain high until later this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are checking screens and river channels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses in the area. This message will be updated by 9pm this evening, Monday 9 August, or as the situation changes.

Following heavy overnight rain, and this morning’s high tide, the water level in the Gurnard Luck is now falling. While heavy showers continue to affect the mainland, very little, if no rain is forecast on the Island for the rest of the day (Monday 09/08/21). During the next high tide, expected at Cowes at 00:45 tomorrow morning (10/08/21), river levels will be a little higher than normal. However, no further flood impacts are currently expected. If the situation changes, then we’ll issue further advice.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall this morning.  Flooding is expected from 1pm this afternoon, Monday 9 August. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge, Shrub Lane and Etchingham areas.

The heavy rainfall is expected to ease by this lunchtime, but further heavy isolated showers are possible throughout the rest of the day today. We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 10 August. We are closely monitoring the situation and are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses in the area. This message will be updated by 9pm this evening, Monday 9 August, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. Since 02:00, half a month's rain (25mm) has fallen at Cowbeech. From 12:30 Monday (09/08/2021) flooding could affect fields, rural roads and approach properties on Mill Lane Hellingly. Minor flooding could also affect Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 14:00, flood water could also affect gardens and approach properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Flooding is less likely in Alfriston but from Monday evening, minor impacts could also affect North Street and Willows Car Park in Alfriston. The rain has now largely cleared to the east, but showers are possible Monday afternoon, which could cause river levels to rise a little higher. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 Monday (09/08/2021) in Hellingly and around midday Tuesday (10/08/2021) in Alfriston, but will continue to be higher than normal until Tuesday evening. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 Monday 09/08/2021.

The River Ouse is high and rising. Since 02:00, about half a month's rain (25mm) has been recorded at Ardingly. From 14:00 09/08/2021, flooding could affect fields, gardens and rural roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. With significant flows coming down both the Uck and the Ouse, from 16:30 water could affect fields and gardens in Barcombe, as well as approach the Anchor Inn. Barcombe Mills Road could also be affected by flood water. Only minor impacts are expected on Sloop Lane, as the river is already nearing its peak there. The rain has now cleared East Sussex, but further showers are possible Monday afternoon. The river should begin to fall by 04:00 Tuesday 10/08/2021, earlier for communities closer to Ardingly. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding indicated in this message. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 09/08/2021.

The River Adur is high and rising following over half a month's rain (32mm) Monday morning. From 19:00 Monday (09/08/2021) flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. While the rain has now cleared away to the east, heavy showers are still possible Monday afternoon. The river might not begin to fall until the early hours of Tuesday morning, and will be higher than normal until Tuesday evening. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding included in this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 09/08/2021.
